title: 109_hr314
content:
The "Combat Meth Act of 2005" is also known as the Combat Meth Act. It includes provisions related to enforcement, such as authorization of appropriations for COPS grants. The Combat Meth Act of 2005 authorizes $15 million for training prosecutors and law enforcement agents in methamphetamine offenses, with a $3 million set-aside for rural communities. Additionally, the Act expands the Methamphetamine Hot Spots Program to include personnel and equipment for enforcement, prosecution, and cleanup. Section 1701(d) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to allow for the hiring of personnel and purchase of equipment to assist in the enforcement and prosecution of methamphetamine offenses and cleanup of affected areas. The Attorney General will allocate funds for hiring and training special assistant United States attorneys to prosecute methamphetamine cases. Training will include techniques, evidence presentation, and knowledge of Federal and State laws related to methamphetamine. Local prosecutors may also be cross-designated as special assistant United States attorneys. United States attorneys can hire additional local prosecutors who are cross-designated to prosecute both Federal and State methamphetamine cases, with a priority on cases related to methamphetamine manufacture or distribution. Authorization of $5,000,000 for fiscal years 2006 and 2007 to support law enforcement in prosecuting methamphetamine-related crimes. SEC. 104. PSEUDOEPHEDRINE AMENDMENTS TO CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES ACT. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to include pseudoephedrine in Schedule V, and regulations regarding prescriptions for pseudoephedrine are updated. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to include pseudoephedrine in Schedule V, with regulations requiring photo identification and a written log for purchases in pharmacies. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to include pseudoephedrine in Schedule V, with regulations requiring photo identification and a written log for purchases in pharmacies, including the name of the person and the substance purchased. The Controlled Substances Act limits the purchase of pseudoephedrine to 9 grams within a 30-day period, with exemptions for prescription dispensing. The FDA Director can exempt products from Schedule V if they are not used in illegal drug manufacturing. The Director can exempt products from Schedule V if they prevent the conversion of the active ingredient into methamphetamine. The FDA Director may authorize the sale of certain substances by non-pharmacists if there is evidence of hardship for a community and if authorized personnel follow the procedures outlined in the Act. TITLE II--EDUCATION, PREVENTION, AND TREATMENT
SEC. 201. GRANTS FOR SERVICES FOR CHILDREN OF SUBSTANCE ABUSERS. Section 519 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include the development of drug endangered children rapid response teams to intervene on behalf of children exposed to methamphetamine. $2,500,000 is authorized to be appropriated for these teams. $2,500,000 authorized for fiscal years 2006 and 2007 for subsection (b)(9) provisions. SEC. 202. LOCAL GRANTS FOR TREATMENT OF METHAMPHETAMINE ABUSE AND RELATED CONDITIONS. Subpart 1 of part B of title V of the Public Health Service Act is amended to prioritize grants for treatment of methamphetamine abuse in rural areas. Grants may be awarded to States, political subdivisions, American Indian Tribes, and nonprofit entities for this purpose. The Secretary shall prioritize entities serving rural areas with increased methamphetamine abuse for grants under Subpart 1 of part B of title V of the Public Health Service Act. Additionally, amendments are made to allocate necessary funds for fiscal years 2006 through 2009. The Secretary will prioritize rural areas with high methamphetamine abuse for grants under the Public Health Service Act. Funds are allocated for fiscal years 2006-2009. A Methamphetamine Research, Training, and Technical Assistance Center will be established. The Secretary will award grants or contracts to establish a center focusing on methamphetamine abuse in rural areas. Applicants must submit an application containing required information. The center will conduct research, training, and technical assistance activities. The center focusing on methamphetamine abuse in rural areas will engage in research, disseminate information, provide technical assistance, and offer training on effective treatment modalities for methamphetamine abuse. Grantees or contractors must submit annual reports to the Administrator. The center established for methamphetamine abuse in rural areas must annually submit a report to the Administrator detailing the previous year's activities, effective treatment modalities, and evidence of treatment success. $3,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2006, with additional funding for 2007 and 2008. SEC. 203. METHAMPHETAMINE PRECURSOR MONITORING GRANTS. The Attorney General may award grants to States for methamphetamine precursor monitoring programs to prevent large-scale sales of precursors for methamphetamine production, educate businesses on the risks, and adjust prescription drug monitoring. The Attorney General may award grants to States for methamphetamine precursor monitoring programs to prevent large-scale sales of precursors for methamphetamine production, educate businesses on the risks, and recalibrate existing prescription drug monitoring programs to track the sale of pseudoephedrine in amounts greater than 6 grams. Grant funds can be used to implement monitoring programs, expand existing programs, and provide training for law enforcement and businesses. The Attorney General may award grants to States for methamphetamine precursor monitoring programs to prevent large-scale sales of precursors for methamphetamine production. Grant funds can be used to improve information sharing between adjacent States, make grants to subdivisions of the State, and authorize appropriations of $5,000,000 for each of the fiscal years 2006 and 2007.
